EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - HOUSTON RAILYARD 

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C. owner and operator of the Houston Railyard, has a

long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the

resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the

design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement

reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release

does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. Other safety

measures such as fire suppression, ambulatory, or evacuation of the community is coordinated and

handled through local emergency response personnel in the community.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Houston Railyard receive propane, iso-butane, n-butane and natural gasoline from the Houston Gas Plant and loads the product directly into railcars for transporation. Several support vessels exist to aid in handling and loading of these NGLs.  A ethyl mercaptan tank is also located at the site to odorize propane cars when requested by customers. 



Regulated substances that are currently stored or will be stored through the time of predictive filing

in this RMP include propane, ethyl mercaptan and flammable mixtures.  Iso- and n-butane are transported through pipeline and directly into railcars but are not stored as a purity product at the Railyard.



For additional detail of the various processes at the Houston Railyard see the plant operations

manager.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



The following is a summary of the accident prevention in place for the process at the facility.

Because the process at the facility that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's

(EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and

Health Administration's (OSHA's)

process safety management (PSM) standard, this summary

addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to

implement accident prevention.



Process Safety Information



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C. keeps a variety of technical documents that are used

to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties

and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and

equipment design basis/configuration inf

ormation. The reference documents are maintained on file

at the facility to provide open access.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure

treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). This information is

supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known

hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For the process, the facility has

documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level,

composition) in key process parameter documents. The facility ensures that the process is

maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained

personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design

and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design

pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in

combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing

inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility

changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest

Liberty M&R, L.L.C., has a comprehensive program to help ensure that

hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled. Within this program, each

process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in

place to manage these hazards.



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., will use one or more of the following techniques to

identify hazards: what-if, checklist, what-if/checklist, hazard and operability (HAZOP), failure mode

and effects analysis (FMEA), or fault tree analysis (FTA). HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of

the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques and will be utilized for each major

process change or renovation. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have

operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and

evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the

team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team

believes such measures are necessary.



Each PHA will address the following:

a) hazards of the process,

b) previous incidents with likely potential for catastrophic consequences,

c) consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls,

d) engineering and administrative control applicable to the hazards and their inter-relationships,

e) facility siting issues,

f) human factors.



The PHA team findings are compiled in a written report and are forwarded to local and corporate

management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is

based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential

accident scenarios assigned that highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation

options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution

of each finding is documented

and retained.



To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate

significantly from the original design safety features, the facility periodically updates and revalidates

the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be

conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operative. The results and findings from

these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to

management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.



Operating Procedures



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., maintains written procedures that address various

modes of operations, such as: unit startup; normal operations; temporary operations; emergency

shutdown; normal shutdown; emergency operations, and initial startup of a new process. These

procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent

training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as

current and accurate. The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary

to reflect changes made through the management of change process. The operating procedures

are centrally located and accessible to all employees.



Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Houston Railyard has

implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.

New employees receive basic training in facility operations unless they provide written certification

that they have the required knowledge, skills and abilities to safely carry out their specific duties and

responsibilities. All MPLX employees at the Houston Railyard will be trained in PSM/RMP requirement

upon hire and prior to working in PSM/RMP processes. All operations employees will undergo

refresher training at least every th

ree years. A training attendance record will be kept for all training

activities and a verification of understanding will be conducted by a performance evaluation or

through testing.



Mechanical Integrity



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., has well-established practices and procedures to

maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and

compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of

mechanical integrity include: training; written procedures; inspections and tests; correcting identified

deficiencies; and applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a

system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.



Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards,

applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, and applicable safe work practices

to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner. Job plans/written procedures help

ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections

and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that

equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a

deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into

service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and

determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity is quality assurance. The Houston Gas Plant

incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure

that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are

used when repairs are made.



Management of Change



MPLX, L.P. and Mar

kWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., has a comprehensive system to manage changes to

all covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment,

chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility

changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to

ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing

controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process

operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these

changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on

the change.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility

modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The PSSR confirm that

construction was completed in accordance with design specifications, that safety, operating,

maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate. The PSSR will be

reviewed and appropriately updated during the management of change process. The PSSR will

ensure that: modifications were installed as described; no other changes were made outside the

original scope of work; operating procedures have been modified and communicated to operating

and maintenance personnel; all necessary tests have been completed prior to start-up; all site

safety, fire protection, and environmental issues have been addressed; the startup plan has been

reviewed; pertinent drawing have been red-lined or updated to as-built requirements; vendor files

have been updated; and training of affected personnel has been performed and documented.



Compliance Audits



To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, MPLX, L.P. and

MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., periodical

ly conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures

and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance

audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit

team members. Team membership will include at least one person knowledgeable of the system

being audited. One member of the team must be qualified to lead the audit and be familiar with the

auditing protocol being administered. Audits will be conducted using the OSHA Verification

Checklist CPL2-2.45a and the EPA Audit Guidance Checklist. The Plant Compliance Coordinator

will maintain a listing of all non-conformances identified during an audit and document closure of

compliance audit action items. The two most recent audit reports will remain on file with the

documentation of closed items.



Incident Investigation



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or

reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental

loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, determine what

error states led to the incident and to develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the

incident or a similar incident. The investigation team consists of the immediate supervisor, one

person knowledgeable in the process, and other members with appropriate experience to investigate

and analyze the incident. The team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a

recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions that

are identified will be promptly addressed, resolved and tracked until they are complete. The final

resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are

reviewed with all employees (including contractors) whose job tasks are relevant to the investigation.

Incident investigat

ion reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed

during PHAs and PHA revalidations.



Employee Participation



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., encourages employees to participate in all facets of

process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range

from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a

member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees will be provided with all information

created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be

involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that

is maintained at the facility.



Hot Work Permit



MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., uses a hot work permit for hot work operations

including grinding, welding, and spark producing activities conducted on or near a covered process.

The hot work permit documents the fire prevention and protection requirements prior to beginning

hot work operations. The permit indicates the days on which hot work may be performed and the

object upon which hot work is to be performed. Hot work permits are kept in a place that is easily

accessible for the workers and on file at the office until the completion of hot work operations.



Contractors



The Houston Railyard uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased

maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process

equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: perform their work in a safe

manner; have the appropriate knowledge and skills; are aware of the hazards in their workplace;

understand what they should do in event of an emergency; understand and follow site safety rules;

and inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by

providing contractors with:

a process overview; information about potential fire, explosion, or toxic

release hazards; emergency response plan requirements; and safe work practices prior to their

beginning work. In addition, the Houston Gas Plant will only select contractors who submit

certification that employees are trained in specifics and safe work practices associated with their job,

and that provide safety performance documentation from the previous three years. Finally, facility

personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their

safety obligations.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The processes at the Houston Railyard have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued

safe operation. The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of

accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.



Universal Prevention Activities



The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at

the Houston Railyard. Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate



potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features



The Houston Railyard has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2)

quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following

types of safety features are used in the covered process:



Release Detection



1. Hand-held hydrocarbon detectors operated by facility personnel.

2. Personnel are on site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.



Release Containment/Control



1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.

2. Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated).

3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)

4. Curbing or dyking to contain liquid releases.

5. Redundant e

quipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control

system).



Release Mitigation



1. Deluge system for specific equipment.

2. Trained emergency response personnel.

3. Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing).



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidents at the Houston Railyard that meet the RMP definition for the five-year accident history.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The Houston Railyard is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The facility maintains

a written emergency action plan, which is in pace to help protect employees and public safety as

well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release

including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of

company staff, local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs. However,

facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from

one of the vessels the Houston Plant would rely on the local fire department to respond.

Employee receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to

operate critical process operations before they evacuate. The Houston Railyard has around the

clock communication capability with appropriate emergency response organization (Fire

Department, LEPC, and Sheriff's Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of

an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

The overall emergency response program for the Houston Railyard is coordinated with the

Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes

periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local

government officials, and industry representatives. The Houston Railyard has around-the-clock

communications c

apability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations

(e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as

well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Houston

Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response

organizations, and the facility provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders

regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Houston Railyard resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the

process. At this time there are no findings to report.



CALCULATION OF QUANTITIES



The calculation of quantities for the facility and the worst-case and alternate-case scenarios have

been performed in a separate spreadsheet that is available upon request.
